What matters is not what we do or say, but being there for each other. 

Dear friends, I am giving out free samples for this gift, the gift of silence, which works in person as well as online. How do you avail yourself of this gift online? If there is a will, there is a way. Be my guest for being creative. I would love to hear from you on your experience with this.

If I want to laugh, I watch ... If I want to scream, I do... If I want to reflect on life, I read The Glass Hotel (2020)  written by award winning author Emily St. John Mandel. This is an exhilarating novel about the dark side of humanity like complicity, guilt, greed, fallibility; and common human needs, such as pursuit of happiness, financial comfort, satisfying relationships. 

This is one of those books that evoked in me the urge to write a sequel, about the book's main character Vincent and her family going through a re-birth, living life all over again, subjecting to similar situations, but creating a different outcome to their destiny with reference to the wisdom they have gained from their first life. 

Why? I believe that all of us grow from our experiences, and may deal with same situations very differently if we are given a second chance. 

Nevertheless, I also believe that as much as personal responsibility is paramount, we also need to generate relevant synergy in partnership with people who are caring and embrace integrity, and reach out for the gifts of faith, hope and love from our Higher Power.

Taking a day trip in the Prince Edward County, and passing by the Military Base in Trenton en-route. Experiencing deep sadness for the fallen soldiers and their family, but also feeling grateful about being part of a nation that promotes peace, community responsibility, and equity. 

Yes, this nation and its stakeholders are far from perfect. Nevertheless, we can choose to point a finger, or ask ourselves what is one thing we can do each day to uphold our hopes and dreams for this nation. 

Special blessings and prayers for everybody who serves and protects and their loved ones.

Preparations: Take precautions against covid at least 21 days in advance, get a good night's sleep, review experience and materials on a baby's initial phase of development, go through sanitization, and put on a kid-friendly outfit. 

Present the gift:  Hold the baby with tender loving care, gaze at him with soft eyes, share jokes, show him around where you are, do a show and tell, wait for his response and follow his lead accordingly, thank him for a good time together, acknowledge his sadness about saying goodbye, bless him, and return him to his lovely parents. 

Follow-up action: Talk to him at the photo taken during the gifting time and rehearse how you will present the next gift to him, and pray with deep gratitude. 

This is THE gift: The gift of Holding Space. Thank you, Baby and other loved ones:)

A:  Aren't you retired? Why are you so busy?

B: Sort of but not really. I just strolled through the gate of retirement and moved into a different area of living and being. I joined a new company: No job application required, lots of fringe benefits, and always get assignments that make a real difference. 

A: That sounds fabulous. Do they have vacancies there?

B: Yes, they do. Look up Kingdom Works on the Internet. I hope that we will serve on the same team, the Dream Team.

Brag...

About nice surprise and genuine care from friends and family over not just one, not just two, not just 3, but four (4) celebrations this Thanksgiving season, 

About the first homecoming to grandparents’ place from a new branch of this growing family,

About the God who bestowed us with faith to go for a walk right before pouring rain, and relish the most gorgeous flowers when the majority of their counterparts have retired for the season. 

They say, bad things happen in threes. I am creating a new idiom, blessings happen in threes and much more. LOL!

post_title: Celebrating a Harvest of Bosc Pears
message:
Harvesting Bosc pears in my own backyard, and rejoicing over the harvest of life: 

Hear and understand the word of God, bear fruits, and yield. (Bible)

May each and everyone of you who reads this post enjoy your fruits!

“I knew the proper words to respond, but didn’t say them, didn’t want to give you the power of making me switch languages, to talk only on your terms.”

I like this quote from the fiction The Leavers by Lisa Ko. It reminds me of the sense of powerlessness that some people subjected to oppression and marginalization experience, and their actions for claiming their very basic right of dignity and humanity.

Remember that rainy day in September?

One of my major transitions was when I returned to school for my second degree. I was going through bereavement, relocated in order to attend the school of my choice and was a stranger in a community, and had to be vigilant how I spend my limited savings from the few years that I had worked after my first degree. I found it hard to focus due to the change in routine and the abovementioned life challenges.

A few weeks after school started, I sat in front of a window in the library overlooking the campus, feeling as if I did not belong, and wondering what I should do next. That soul searching awakened in me my reason for returning to school, that is, to enrich my professional competency, so that I can soar higher and farther for my hopes and dreams in health care services.

I got out of the library, and there was no turning back: I started every morning bright and early fighting for my survival as a student as if my life and death depends on it, ended up being the student with the highest average in the whole faculty that year, and acquired recognition and income through a combination of scholarship and professional practice related summer jobs. I am forever grateful for this educational opportunity, which has opened different doors for me to help make a difference to the lives of people I serve.

Discouraging times are like the state of off season, when everything looks dead and dormat. However, we need to remain faithful in what we do and hopeful about the best times of our lives lying ahead of us. I claimed the promise of the Lord over my family, that we would find favour in the eyes of God and man, and the weak would say that I am strong. We have experienced results already. Alleluia!
Knock, and it will be opened. (Luke 11:9-10)

Culture says, when a baby is born, he is already one year old. 
God said, I have formed you and taken care of you from day 1, right from the time when you are formed.
My heart said, thank you for waving back when I waved at you and blessed you for the first time over videoconferencing shortly after you have been born.

Let' s thank God and the wisdom of culture, my beloved son and daughter in law!

Happy first morning, my dear grandson! 

Thank you to everyone who has generously prayed for and blessed this humble family. You know who you are. Cheers!

From the overjoyed grandparents

The Van Gogh World Tour and the Sunflower Farm in Beaverton, Ontario have been the talk of the town for some of us for a while. I have a share of related joy in my home since I received the Sunflower painting on my birthday recently from a good friend. Quiet fun:)

Welcoming a new life, 
Helping someone to grow into their God given destiny, 
Witnessing their hopes and dreams coming to pass, 
Taking an inventory of what we learnt from our walk together, 
Looking forward to the extension of the legacy as the then baby is going to enter into fatherhood himself. 
Happy Birthday Son! Prayers, blessings and enjoy!

I have gone to corn mazes, but this is the first time that I went to a sunflower maze. This visit certainly brings laughter for the lovely child guests as they run around. It has brought out positivity and hope in me as an adult as I soaked in the sunshine and the sunny message that these flowers convey through their liveliness. What strikes me the most is my experience with the flowers that look tired and fading: It is easy for me to be hard on them, but I chose to celebrate the cycle of life and thank them for inspiring me to enjoy each stage. Alleluia!

A: I lost my sunglasses. I am usually very careful, and can't imagine this happening to me. 
B: I saw a pair of sunglasses that look like yours. However, it never occurred to me that they were yours exactly for the reason that you stated just now. 
A: So much for worrying about you and your carefree demeanor. It is my turn now. 
B: No worries, I will go there now, and hope that your sunglasses are still there. 
A: Thanks honey. I love you. 

Don't make assumptions about oneself or others. We all have our days:) Little things like this help us to appreciate and value each other. Let's use our "zoom lens" to identify each other's beauty instead of flaws. 

Thank you for some of you my friends who have been there for me. May you enjoy your helper(s) AND recognition for your helping hand as well.
Spectacular piece of sculpture at ZimArt Rice Lake Gallery, Ontario, titled Lingering Thoughts, reminding me of a few lovely young ladies that I am privileged to interface with. 🙆

Reading The Leavers by Lisa Ko, what struck me the most is one of the main characters Polly, an undocumented Chinese immigrant working at a nail salon in New York who disappeared on her six year old son Deming, who portrays her inner world together with its hopes and dreams, joy and challenges through her monologue addressed to Deming. She as she said, found it hard to “stay put”, and keeps making active efforts to pursue her hopes and dreams. One may despise her for making certain choices, but I appreciate her bravery, genuine care for people around her, and subtle dedication to her son.

As I keep listening to Polly talking to her son in this book, I feel as if I have got to know this fictional character like a real person, and pray and wish that all her dreams and hopes will come true.

After all, Polly’s story is the story of a lot of us regardless of our birth place and other social identities. This is a story about going after our own hopes and dreams while experiencing our own humanity.

Watching people on the beach, I feel as if this is a glimpse of paradise. There are several parties here, and each of them bears social identities different from other parties. In spite of the diversities among the different parties, they share one very important thing: a positive spirit, which fills the air with streams of laughter and the aroma of food. All of them seem to be soaked in a good time of their own choice: playing water sports, exploring the trail, singing songs, eating different styles of food, sleeping, and snoring... Nobody stops anybody from their preferred activity. 

It looks as if everyone is doing nothing important, and not in a rush to go anywhere. However, this may be the best day of the summer or life for some of them. 

As I bathe in the positive spirit, I have flashbacks about another group get together just the night before, which is a contrast to this scene today. I bow down and pray that people (including me)  can bring this kind of spirit in our leisure activities into our serious business, that is, respect each other, and connect through positivity and mutuality.

She said, "It is always fun to cook for your loved ones. However, be mindful of how you cook. Take chicken for example, you can prepare deep fried chicken, pan fried chicken, curry chicken, steamed chicken, chicken congee, or chicken soup. Other than individual preference, it may have something to do with age too." 

The naughty side of me is saying, I will always tell you that I like nothing but deep fried chicken. Ha! Ha!

You look at me, and wonder if I want to dye my hair. 
I look at you, and question if you know that you are bald at the back. 
Then, we look at each other, and both break out in laughter. 
What matters is not so much how we look anymore, but how we grow old together, enjoy each other, and use our health and other gifts from the Creator to serve.
Love in action from our family!

My father-in-law said, "When you go and view an open house, focus on the structure of the house, not what the current owner uses to decorate the house and which will not be there when you move in. "

My mother-in-law said, " Salt and pepper are the best spices."

My God said, " All ye who are heavily laden, come to me, and I will give you rest. "

Each and every one of them reminds me about the importance of simplicity, and the blessings we can get from exercising it.

I learnt a new recipe lately for making tasty nutritious fry noodles:  
1. Give the dry noodles a hot bath until they get tender, 
2. give them a cold bath right after to tighten up their skin, 
3. dress them up with the sauce of your choice AND oil in a pot, and help them to mingle with their friends the sauce and oil by tossing them around, 
4. warm up the frying pan, and let the noodles dance in it without any additional oil or sauces, 
5. invite the noodles' friends from different walks of life, e.g. hot peppers, spinach, mushroom, to come to the party in the frying pan, which includes dances and a sauna (yes, complimentary spa for everyone from you!), 
6. after everyone has enjoyed the sauna in the frying pan for a while, tell them that you need their help to entertain yourself and your guests, 
7. The grand finale: Serve your lovely cuisine the fry noodles. 

The above information has brought a lot of joy to the taste buds among my loved ones. I am just in a silly mood, and decided to present them accordingly.

My friends, May you enjoy this recipe as much as I do!

post_title: Reflections on Oppression Happening At Home In Canada
message:
Listening to different voices commenting on the discovery of the children died in the residential schools, wondering what the children themselves might have wanted to say. 

Honoring each and every precious soul who suffered because of oppression, inviting ourselves to stand in solidarity in our little corner to not just prevent this from happening, but also pray for wisdom to shine the light of hope that transcends us.

Reminding myself that individuals and systems are responsible for the abuse of power, and not the God who created all of us human kind.

Happy Canada Day everyone.
From your friend at the Sculpture Forest, Haliburton, Ontario.
Message from my apple trees today: celebrate each stage of my life, encourage me everyday, and be patient about the time it takes me to be "fruitful" (whatever that means:)

D: How are you?
C: Tired.
D: This is "heart tiredness". 
A real friend Daisy warmed my heart. A real God Jesus rekindled my fire.
Grateful!
Mr. Chipmunk: " I am small but mighty, by the grace of our Creator."

post_title: Quotable Quote From "Pull of the Stars" by Emma Donoghue
message:
This book just published last year, when we are in the middle of the pandemic of this era, is worth reading. It made me reflect on what we go through as a human kind currently: The book is about a time when Ireland was doubly ravaged by war and disease, Nurse Julia Power works at an understaffed hospital in the city center, where expectant mothers who have come down with the terrible new Flu are quarantined together.

Here's a snapshot of this book from the following quote. 
"Eileen Devine had walked along a cliff edge all her adult life, and this flu had only tipped her over.”
– Julia

This quote reminds me that we all die no matter who we are and what the cause of the death is, it is important for us to honor the systemic challenges that individuals are dealing with, and if possible, support them in their walk.

post_title: The Innocents by Michael Crummey: Reflections on the Issue of Resilience
message:
The Innocents is the coming-of-age story of Evered and Ada Best, young siblings who find themselves orphaned and alone in a remote, isolated cove in northern Newfoundland after their parents and infant sister succumb to fatal illnesses.

I gave 4 out of 5 for my rating on this book. I am very touched by the author’s expression of empathy for the two youngsters in the way that he stages the different scenes in the book.

I appreciate the repeated description of the self doubts of the main characters in the book. They are so human. What makes the difference between them and the rest of us is that the book portrays the main characters' self doubts in a very authentic manner, and the rest of us may either deny them, or try too too hard to hide them.

They are real survivors. They remind me of one of my very respectable mentors who had a similar childhood like Ada and Evered. She ended up not just surviving, but grew up becoming a mentor and source of inspiration for not just me, but a lot of her students and younger siblings.

Yes, I certainly would recommend this book to a friend. However, I would also caution my friend that they have to be prepared for triggers and emotional moments, and deal with them accordingly.

post_title: Living the First and the Last
message: Live everyday as if it is the last and...first day of our life, and be thankful and rejoice always. May you embrace this blessing my friends.

post_title: Sharing and Supporting Each Other as a Group Through Artwork
message: We come from dust and go back to dust. Honoring our Creator for the garden of life and everyone who has brought their gift to build and sustain it.

We can regret about our inability to do certain things, such as cooking more elaborate meals for our children when they were young due to multiple challenges in raising a family. I chose to cook a special meal for my children yesterday, not out of guilt, but out of love for them and gratitude for family togetherness.

post_title: On Reading"Eat a Peach" by David Chang
message:
What a treat to start this first long weekend of the summer with a good book. Yes, I have started to take a bite with my treat, a memoir titled " Eat a Peach" by world-renowned chef David Chang. 

This book sparked in me fascinating as well as burdensome memories, about marginalization, willpower, family ties, spirituality. Finally, I was in tears reflecting on the issue of passion. 

My passion is to engage in a professional practice that instills faith, hope, and love. I started this pursuit when I was 12 and helped to cut the toenails of the residents in an old folks' home and being their sounding board at the same time. As an older adult, I am still pursuing this passion, in roles much more sophisticated and diversified than my teenage years. 

Grateful! I am not a victim but a victor by the grace of God and with the inspiration of the hosts of angels he has sent to me over the years!

post_title: From the Outdoors to the Indoors: Nice Surprises
message: Nice surprises, one after the after, unstoppable, non- stop. It is not me, but my loved ones, my God. Much appreciation!

A bunch of us are crazy about nature and flowers, and at this time of the year, cherry blossoms. This morning, as I was half awake and gently asked the birds to do their concert after the sun is fully out, I realized that they are not the only ones working. The flowers that were budding last night started to bloom as well. 

Wow! There are nice surprises every day, and they are there bright and early even before we open our door! Just look for them, and enjoy!

A woman prayed to her god for her husband's healing. Her prayer is that she rather got a shorter life span in exchange for his healing. 
Fast forward, she was introduced to the God Jesus Christ, and finally realized that He died for her and all mankind unconditionally, and she does not have to give anything to get her prayers answered. 
She was released from the chain of fear and obligation for her well intentioned but misinformed faith practice, and accepted Jesus as her personal Savior and Lord in life and death. 
This is my Mom, a woman who sacrificed her entire life for her husband, children, and everyone whom she interfaced with. 
Rounds of applause in recognition of this very special woman in my life!

post_title: Simple But Deep and Long-Lasting Joy!

message: Product of partnership between God and the green thumbs in my family. Grace!

post_title: Genesis and Reflections on Lifelong Issues
message:
The Book of Genesis interested me to start with because it talks about Joseph and Abram: I have loved these two people and their walk with God for the longest time. 

Through the study of Genesis at the Bible Study Fellowship for the time period September 2020 to May 2021, I have been inspired to reflect upon the following life related issues: 

1. How would I make corrective actions to my wrongs?

2. How would I deal with my own experience of oppression?

3. How will I face my own death before my God?

4. How do I leave my best inheritance, that is, knowledge of our Lord Jesus and living in his light, for the future generations?

Bouquets of appreciation for our group leader Ruth LeBlanc for going beyond the call of her duty in creating a community of prayer and edification throughout the week among the sisters in the group, and I feel most privileged to be in fellowship with each and everyone of the sisters in the group. 

Joy in the Lord!

post_title: Thursday Snapshot of a Caregiver Support Group
message:
It is Thursday afternoon. Our team was wondering if some of our participants may be delayed in attending the caregiver support group. Everyone is so busy cleaning, cooking, making the bed, confirming doctor's appointments, returning phone calls from caring family and friends. Who has time for a caregiver support group as much as this is what they need? 

Sure enough, the participants slowly joined the meeting. We did mindfulness to relax, echoed each other's difficult experiences in our walk with our loved one's health care journey, created artwork to celebrate our "love in action", talked about our joy in spending time with our loved ones, and finally, exchanged a word of encouragement with each other. It is always delightful to see how everyone comes into the group session looking tired and share upon their departure from the session that they feel re-energized. 

This is a snapshot of what we do at the Caregiver Support Group I have been blessed by people who shone their light on me in my caregiver role, and I value the opportunity to give back to the community through involvement in this group.

I have my share of the interesting journey with taking the vaccination. 

My most caring family doctor worked in coordination with a vaccine specialist, advised that it would be safe for me to take the vaccination in spite of my history of allergy. I said thank you and was still ambivalent. 

My angel told me that it is my turn to get the vaccine. I said thank you and thought that I would wait until the reports on the choice of vaccines are not as murky. 

My lovely son, who is a father-to-be, reminded me that I need to take the second dosage of the vaccination before I hold my first grandchild who is scheduled to gracefully join the family in the early fall. All of a sudden, I woke up to the fact that my vaccination is not just my business, it is part of the grand mission of the family. 

Fast forward, it is now 24 hours after my vaccination. I woke up symptom-free, greeted the sunshine of dawn with a grin, and a full load of gratitude for everybody who has supported me in the process (you know who you are), and most of all, my God who constantly reminds me of His presence and loving-kindness. 

As always, I learned and grew from the experience:   
1. Book online, and do not waste time lining up on the phone. 
2. Eat a light healthy snack before leaving home. 
3. Go with an escort if at all possible. 
4. Be friendly and cooperative to the crew at the vaccination clinic, with the full understanding that they have a tough and possibly health compromised job. 
5. Take proactive actions against an anxiety attack from the standard questions that they ask at the registration desk. 
6. Wait patiently. If it is your turn, they will call you. They do not get any perks for holding you up. 
7. Unpack the buckets of advice from all the wizards for dealing with the initial discomfort immediately after the vaccination: drink lots of fluid, go for a long walk, eat light but healthy, sing, laugh and dance celebrating the day, and retire in bed early. 

Yay! Let's go through this era of history as victors, not victims! Blessings!

Me: Good day, Obed-edom! I heard that God had indeed blessed you. I don't mean to be rude, you and your sons are just gatekeepers at the temple. 

Obed-edom: I was struggling with this question in my early career too. Nonetheless, over the years, I get up every morning and feel great about going to work. 

Me: Okay. You feel blessed that you have a stable job. But, is your job not boring? You merely stand there, open and close doors, and maybe once in a while deal with some troubleshooting. 

Obed-edom: Yes, that is what my job description says. However, I have done more than that:  direct and instruct those going to worship in the courts of the sanctuary, encourage those that are timorous, and screen the visitors for safety concerns. 

Me: Anybody can do that job. You don't need training for it. 

Obed-edom: You tell me. Our whole team is made up of mighty people of valour, strong and able. Oh! If I have to make a complaint, I do not agree with the rule that only males are picked for the job. I wish that they would have been more inclusive of our female counterparts in the selection process. 

Me: Some of them probably took this job because that was the only thing available to them. 

Obed-edom: I am afraid that this is not the case. For your information, one of us, namely, Shelemiah, is actually a counselor, being highly regarded for his insight, and got another award the other day for his long-term service and numerous "likes" in his customer review. 

Me: Would you encourage me to apply for the position of gatekeeper when there is an opening? 

Obed-edom: Why not? My friend, it is not what we do, but how we approach it that matters. I practice what I preach: keep myself healthy, learn to take risks in order to get the job done, exercise sound judgment, but most of all, figure out what God has called me to do, and do it in a way that brings blessings. In the process, God blesses me even without me bugging Him.

Me: Got you. That is why you are an inspiration and a person greatly blessed. 

Note: Reflections on 1 Chronicles 26: 1-19 in the Bible

When it seems the magic slipped away
We find it all again on Christmas Day. 
(Believe sang by Josh Groban)

Shuffling snow on a Christmas Day? This could be a prime time for a self-pity party. However, doing it concurrently in a social distance compliant manner with my neighbour helped to turn this into one of my best Christmas gifts this year, that is, a concert named Gratitude. He talked about how he was not able to do any of this when he suffered from a life-limiting disease but has now fully recovered from it. He talked about how he values the neighbours and tries to provide support whenever he can. He talked about the natural cycle of life, and how he praises God when he gets up every morning. 

When I feel as if Christmas is not the same this year due to the pandemic, the snow shuffling this morning brought back in me the 
spirit of innocent joy, which works like magic for brightening up the day. 

Dear Friends, May you experience this magic like what I did this Christmas, and especially when it feels as if we are exhausted from walking in a pitch dark tunnel, and don't know where this is going and when we will be out of it. Warmest wishes!

post_title: Flesh of Rice, Blood of Tea
message:
It was Holy Communion time at the Sunday Service over videoconferencing this morning. I had no unleavened bread or wine at home to participate in this activity. At the spur of the moment, I realized that I had rice and tea. That is exactly what I used for this activity. 

For the whole afternoon, I asked myself, "What would Jesus say about my practice this morning?" I cannot read the mind of Jesus of course:). However, this experience helped me to reflect on my interactions with people: Genuine respect and cultural responsiveness is appreciating individuals' way of achieving a goal with resources available and culturally meaningful to them.

“Not everything that can be counted counts.
And... not everything that counts can be counted”.
(Albert Einstein)

From the most remote place on earth I call out to you in my despair. Lead me up to an inaccessible rocky summit! (Psalm 61:2) 

I had a difficult day today in my role as a caregiver in spite of my usual optimism and faith practice. 

This evening, I heard the above sentence from the Bible twice within one hour. I heard it for the first time in a zoom meeting. I got out of the session, and heard it again in one of my dear friend's FB post. 

No matter how busy some of my family members and friends are, they are always there providing support and prayers. Today is no exception. I am forever grateful to them. They are like angels. 

As the day comes to a close, my God met me right in my living room, right on the zoom screen, waving at me, speaking to me through the aforementioned sentence, making sure that I know that He has been there together with my angels. Alleluia!

Have a nice day means...
Submerging in the blessings of friends and family from near and afar while scrolling through the seas of messages or seeing them online, 
Getting clarity about our health care, 
Walking with someone in their journey from darkness to light, 
Smelling the organic coffee and melty blueberry muffin in front of the hearth, 
Marvelling at the never-ending boardwalk over the marsh and by the lakeside at Cliffview Park, 
Spoiling our sense of touch with the crispy and colorful homegrown maple and apple tree leaves at the yard, 
Quietly celebrating the triumphs of our children and loved ones in their dreams and hopes, 
Amusing over a rescheduled Thanksgiving dinner in the late fall within our social bubble upon some members' safe return from an essential out of the country visit and post quarantine, 
Achieving our shared mission as a team while playing the game The Minder, 
Shedding happy tears over Josh Groban's heartwarming lyrics:  

Believe in what your heart is saying
Hear the melody that's playing
There's no time to waste
There's so much to celebrate
Believe in what you feel inside
And give your dreams the wings to fly
You have everything you need
If you just believe
If you just believe
If you just believe
If you just believe
Just believe
Just believe. 

Yes, I have a lot of nice days. 

Dear friends, may you have a nice day, and I would love to enjoy the privilege of hearing from you about it.

If someone said that you have a big heart, you probably would be pleased, for this means that you are kind and generous (Merriam Webster Dictionary). 

Cindy taught me a different lesson on this term today: She shared that she had often been told that she has a big heart, which is a derogatory term in her mother tongue, meaning that she does not care about anything or anyone. 

What are these people talking about? Just go and visit Cindy at her hair salon, you would know why I am concerned. From the minute you go into her salon, she would make sure that she takes all kinds of safety precautions to protect you against COVID, fully understands your expectations, and brings out the best in you through her state of the art hairstyling service. 

Let's start a campaign against labelling, start today. 

Dear friend, what is your experience with labelling? Would you join me in this campaign?

We went for a walk when the sun was smiling at us. However, when we were halfway from our destination, it started to spit. We did not want to get sick from the rain and gathered that we could always take a bus home when we got to the destination. We were there, but it felt as if it took forever for the bus to come. We decided to return home on foot instead. 

Halfway through our walk home, the rain stopped, although the gray clouds continued to hide the sun, and laughing at our nervousness about getting wet. 

As I am writing this journal, we are home, sipping a cup of heavenly steamy tea. Our hair is dry, and we have not sneezed. 

The simple common experience today has encouraged us at this time when we are dealing with a difficult situation: Just keep moving forward, the situation is going to come to pass, AND we will be fine, our God is still in control even when we are not and in spite of our best efforts. Amen!

Double Ninth Festival Eve, the night before the special day of the year for paying respect for our ancestors, I reminisced about my time with each and every one of them and arrived at a spot in memory lane where my parents told me how much they valued each and every one of the visits from us from across the ocean. 

At that time, I felt a lot of pressure to visit them regularly in spite of a range of intervening variables, and sometimes murmured in my heart, "Then why bothered encouraging us to see the world and migrate in the first place?" 

Now, being a parent myself, I can relate more to their way of thinking. They wanted their children to have the liberty to soar and go after their dreams and hopes, and even at the expense of the discomfort of the empty nest. 

Thank you, Mom and Dad, for your storge unconditional tender loving care!
Looking at some adorable feathered friends, honoring the theme of mutuality. Thank you to each and every one of you whom I have been privileged to interface with. You know who you are. Hooray!

post_title: Some Finish the Race Faster Than Others
message:
A: I do not like visits to the hospital. 
B: I cherish hope each of the visits bears for health care issues. 

A: I may not be able to do this forever. 
B:  Enjoy the journey, and finish this race proudly. 

A: I miss my loved ones when they are gone. 
B: Value each other, create fond memories, with the understanding that death is an inevitable transition, and we will eventually spend time with each other in eternity in the presence of our Creator. 

Reflections on living while soaked in the blessings of relationships, service opportunities, and the exquisite attire of Fall.

We have hit record high for COVID 19 outbreaks? It is disappointing, and it feels as if we are going in circles in the woods, and don't exactly know when we will get out of it. 

Nevertheless, we have made impressive improvements previously. Let's put faith in each other , our authorities, and most of all, the Creator, and take action in going through this together.

This will be a different kind of Thanksgiving for sure with financial challenges among some of us, restricted access to venues in the community, and most of all, little or no family members and other loved ones around the table. 

Regardless, let's manage our emotions instead of being ruled by them. Peace!

Chilly, cloudy, drizzling: It is just another typical autumn Sunday afternoon weather. 
Need some exercise and the weather makes it difficult for us to enjoy a walk outdoors: Go to a mall with skylights. 
Want to munch on something while I am out, but there is not much that is appetizing: Enjoy the walk, work up an appetite, go home, and prepare the meal of my choice. 
Can't meet up with people due to social distancing: Make arrangements to go for walks with them and save the trouble of entertaining each other at home. 

This can be a depressing Sunday afternoon, but I am filled with contentment as I came home from my walk, gobble the first bite of my early supper, and send my blessings remotely to each and everyone close to my heart.

I just saw the reminder from Anne (thank you) about breast cancer prevention week in September, which obviously has come and gone. Regardless of our gender, let's wake up celebrating and valuing every day. Prayers for everyone's holistic health. Cheers!

Feeling disappointed about someone's behaviors? Maybe we can learn to accept the fact that this is a symptom of the individual's personal challenge, and not to take their behaviours personally. Calm down!

Feeling ignored by a loved one who lately seems to have all kinds of time for someone but not you? Maybe the person is going after a relationship that we have always wanted them to enjoy. Rejoice!

post_title: The Ancient Greek Types of Love
message:
Wondering about an interpersonal issue? I have found a check-in on the nature of the relationship, with reference to the following Greek words on love, helpful: 

Eros (romantic, passionate love)
Philia (affectionate love)
Agape (selfless, universal love)
Storge (familiar love)
Mania (obsessive love)
Ludus (playful love)
Pragma (enduring love)
Philautia (self-love)

Warmest wishes!

Enjoy cooking: 
with love for my "guests", 
with thanksgiving to our Lord God, 
with imagination while plating it, as if I am sculpting a beach at dawn, a garden with blooming flowers and shrubs ..., 
with healthy eating in mind before my kids complain again that I am trying to fatten them. Ha! Ha!

post_title: If I Had a Million Dollars
message:
Listening to the lyrics of the song "If I had a million dollars, I would buy you...", I feel as if our loved ones must be quite rich, because they keep sending us gifts: leg massager for post-surgery numbness, Disneyplus for watching Hamilton on line when our plan to watch it in the theatre is pending, homemade dumplings for Canada Day, real crocodile soup for lung health, heavenly donuts from Kensington Market, playing bocce balls at the backyard, celebrating a special landmark in life in a creative way, laughing together, unstoppable flows of heartwarming greetings and words of caring. The rest of the list can exhaust all of the space on my computer. 

I am privileged to have all these rich connections in my life. Thank God!

I was doing gardening, in the steamy hot afternoon this Father's Day, as a gift for the father of the house and in preparation for a family celebration. Here's a sweet fruit of wisdom that I received from a 4-year-old neighbor when I had a brief encounter with him through the fence. 

Me: Have you found your ball? 
Boy: Where?
Me: I found your ball on my side of the fence, and I threw it over to you just now. It is now at the far end of your backyard, away from your house. 
Boy: (Ran over according to the above information) I found it. 
After a few minutes. I felt that my back was getting wet. I turned around, I saw the boy spraying at me with his water gun. 
I was a little irritated, thinking that he was making fun of me. 
Me: ( With a fake but polite smile) I am cool enough. I do not need to get wet. 
The boy walked away, started to play with his ball. 
As I continued working on my garden, I looked at the boy's behavior from a different perspective, and I talked to him through the fence again. 
Me: Thank you for helping to give water to my flowers. They surely are thirsty. 
Boy: You are welcome. 
He stopped playing with the ball, watched me attending to my garden, and wore the sunniest smiling face for the whole time. 

Yes, my young neighbor taught me the wisdom to express gratitude and approach frustrations from a different perspective. 

Dear Readers of this post, I wonder how you would have dealt with a similar situation?

I complained to a girlfriend that the flowers in my yard have not blossomed like last year. 

It so happened that within half an hour, another girlfriend sent me flowers with no knowledge whatsoever about my grumbling. 

In the middle of the night, a friend informed that he had approached a number of stores about a medical supply that he needs in a time-sensitive manner, but none of them have the product in stock. 

The next morning, it so happened that I had no choice but do my fairly infrequent grocery shopping during this time of social distancing. In the middle of shopping, I remembered my friend's need, casually walked over to the pharmacy of the store, and was ecstatic when the pharmacist handed me the last bottle of the product in their inventory. 

In the Bible, Ruth, a new immigrant in her deceased husband's home town, was struggling with social isolation and poverty. 

It so happened that she ran into a person who shared her core values around dedication to family and faith in God. Fast forward, the two were happily married to each other. 

Coincidence does happen, but when it happens so many times, we wonder if we have to redefine it as something else. 

What do you think, my dear reader?

A: Pray, and God will answer. 
B: (Pray in silence) Yes, I just did. 
A: Are you sure that you will be okay this time?
B: I have made my best efforts and will continue to do so. Did you not say pray and He will answer. It is now His problem, not mine. 

Does this sound familiar? 

Let's enjoy our trek!

"We find ourselves afraid and lost. We were caught off-guard by an unexpected, turbulent storm. We have realized that we are on the same boat, all of us fragile and disoriented ... all of us called to row together, each of us in need of comforting the other." (Pope Francis, Good Friday 2020) 

A dear friend gave us a homemade sticky rice wrap in a way that adheres to guidelines around physical distancing, in spite of the unusual challenges involved in grocery shopping and traveling during the pandemic. She is also among the high-risk population due to age. Yes, some people whom we appreciate are out there to rescue the world from the pandemic as well as world hunger which compromises the well being of over 820 million people in the global village (United Nations Report, 2019), but it is the average folks that make up the majority of this “boat”. Through their gift of love; they keep the boat afloat and moving forward. 

As I say grace for the food, I thank our Lord Jesus for the food and the gift of love from this friend

post_title: We Don't Always Recognize That We Are Soaked in a Blessing Until Much Later
message:
Here’s a prime example of this. 

When we travelled in the Netherlands, it was brought to our attention that they have a garden, namely, Keukenhof, which is the world’s largest spring garden. Since we were in the area, we decided to squeeze a visit there in our busy and exciting itinerary. We were delighted that we got in shortly before they were closed. Sure enough, the 7 million bulbs, the 800 varieties of tulips, the feast of the eyes, the refreshing aroma in the air and the tranquility of the garden permeated our hearts and renewed our minds. 

This unique experience did not leave such an unforgettable mark in our memory lane until we returned home from across the pond: Our friends familiar with the Netherlands uttered admiration for our chance to enjoy this awesome garden during the peak of the beautiful but brief blooming season, which may take a great deal of planning and buckets of “luck”. 

Our planner was the Creator. In Him there is no such thing as luck. His loving kindness is what matters.

post_title: A Time for Everything and Enjoying the Time We Have
message:
Celebrating the birthday of a family member today over zoom. He has taught me about experiencing the message behind the word Immanuel (God with us). 

We all know that there is a time for everything. There is a time to be born, and a time to die. Some of us may either live as if we are in a fool’s paradise presuming that we will be around forever, or are overly anxious about death and the suffering we go through in the dying process.

He has survived his chronic illness to the amazement of a lot of people. Instead of moaning and groaning about his prognosis and pain, he enjoys and serves his sail in life with his Lord God one day at a time.

Happy Birthday!

post_title: Stress Management 101 During Our Covid 19 Journey
message: Reflecting on our blessings, such as meet ups with spring and cherry blossom over the years, envisioning our next visit when the pandemic is over, and immersing in glee!

post_title: Yelling About Love, Stressing About Stress Management
message:
Found myself caught in a feud over video conferencing about best practices for coping with the pandemic, and protecting each other’s health. A discussion about love and stress management turned into yelling, screaming and telling each other what to do. In spite of my best efforts, I was at a loss as to how to contribute to the discussion, and had no choice but practised the “silence is golden” rule. 

The feud ended, but it continued to haunt me in the middle of the night, wondering where this fight among people I care about is going. 

The toss and turn in bed finally came to an end with the coming of dawn: Instead of arguing how to love each other, how about if we show love for each other this Easter morning in a way that we know how, and still observe physical distancing, and… we did. Alleluia!

And God is able to bless you abundantly, so that in all things at all times, having all that you need, you will abound in every good work. (2 Corinthians 9: 8)

Just finished watching the movie Ordinary Love. It is about a couple struggling with the wife's breast cancer and survived it. While processing my flashbacks and triggers about the journey of people that I care about a lot, the movie also helped me to harvest the lessons that I learnt from them:    

* Everyone is in the challenge together, and needs to stand in solidarity in coping with it instead of taking things out on each other. 

* Challenges can open the door for resolving unfinished business like grief and losses. 

* Enjoy each day to the best of our ability and refuse to let the challenge rule us.

A group of us were in a party, exchanging foot and elbow hugs in a lighthearted manner and dancing silly. Someone excitedly shouted out, " We all need a new beginning, a new house, a new ..., ...., ...."

While everyone was applauding and building the list together, the usually most laid back bro among us started to rap, " We need to find a new way of managing our house, ...., ...., ..., who and what we have." 

Then... everyone was gone, and there was so much silence that you could hear a pin dropping on the floor. 

Oh! I woke up from a dream.

post_title: You Are Not Too Old to Learn
message:
When my lovely children coached me to set up my own whatsapp account, they murmured, " You are not too old to learn."  

I admire my children, and love them to pieces. However, I am afraid that other than the two of them my lovely coaches, I heard a lot of messages that are contrary to the above saying: "You are too old to learn."

Today, when someone asked for volunteers to help set up a whatsapp group, I took it upon myself to provide assistance, and at the same time gave myself a chance to advance my relationship with the cyber world. 

I fiddled around with my own whatsapp account, got my husband to work with me in doing a test group, stumbled for a bit before I got a handle on this new skill, was "on the job" within half an hour, and ... I made it. 

Yes, it is very affirming to realize that this gal is still young enough to learn, and hopefully help to make a difference in the process.

When I remember you upon my bed, and meditate on you in the watches of the night; for you have been my help, and in the shadow of your wings I will sing for joy. (Psalm 63:6-7) 

Retiring in bed, trying to fall asleep, but the imminent impact of covid 19 on the global community and my loved ones and the passing of a woman of faith and great friend this week flooded my heart and soul, and my drowsiness was drowned. 

In this seemingly untimely waking moments, I asked the Lord to help me remember the blessing of encounter with my great friend and other loved ones, more than that...

* turn my sense of vulnerability into the fuel for living each day to the fullest, and
* walk with others heart to heart while fulfilling our social responsibility around physical distancing. 

Amen!

I went to the Walmart this morning at 7 a.m. during the senior hours related to Covid 19. I was nicely surprised to find toilet tissues. I was low on stock on this household item, tried my best to observe social responsibility and just purchased one pack. 

I am grateful to God, the businesses as well as fellow citizens with remarkable social conscience.

post_title: Reflections on a Movie About a Certain Social Enterprise
message: Watched the movie on a top notch social enterprise with the Tuesday special. The "hero" of the movie seems to be a prototype of the American Dream. However, instead of feeling envious of him and his second wife, I felt nauseous as I got out of the theatre: If fulfilling one's hopes and dreams means being a functional alcoholic, a womanizer, a cheater, a manipulator, and a phony philanthropist, how can one rest and soundly asleep at night unless he shuts his guilt conscience out of his bedroom door?

“Surrender yourself to the Lord, and wait patiently for him”(Psalm 37:7a GW).

I cracked up over this line in a show that I watched lately: 

Actor A started to speak in a language other than English on stage in a show conducted in English. Actor B commented: " Don't speak in Swedish. The audience doesn't know what you say." Actor B responded: "You speak in English, and are you sure that the audience understands what you are saying?"

This triggers the following thought in me: We assume that the spoken word is the sole means of communication, which may not necessarily be the absolute truth. For instance, "silence" can be a language on its own. When we observe silence before the Lord, we can use this as a gesture to demonstrate our willingness to wait upon Him.

Just got home from the movie Moana, and felt a bundle of warm fire in my heart: According to the story line, Moana was chosen by the ocean to restore the universe to its former paradise like state, and the action required was to return the “heart” to the angry earth goddess. After a number of unsuccessful attempts, Moana, out of desperation, was about to give up. Her deceased grandma’s spirit asked her to reflect on who she is. She responded with the message that she was chosen to fulfill her mission in order to rescue her beloved family and people. 

In spite of how many assertiveness training I have attended, I dare not to say that I am the chosen one. However, Moana reminded me how to deal with my sense of desperation.

For this reason I bow my knees before the Father, from whom every family in heaven and on earth is named, that according to the riches of his glory he may grant you to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in your inner being, so that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith—that you, being rooted and grounded in love, may have strength to comprehend with all the saints what is the breadth and length and height and depth, and to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God. (Ephesians 3:14-19)

In the midst of the joyous Christmas music from the radio that filled my space, the DJs kept sharing story after story on the children in the Sick Kids' Hospital, and finally the heartwarming news that a celebrity's 3 year old son suffering from liver cancer will return home for Christmas. 

I echoed the words in the Book of Ephesians, that each and every family that has a loved one undergoing a medical condition, regardless of age and the nature of the illness, may experience the healing touch, strength and love of the Lord. I believe that I have the gift of empathy, but I have never felt the yearnings of these families as much as I do now, when the situation is happening in my family. Nevertheless, the silver lining around the situation is that we can all learn to approach this as an opportunity to experience the fullness of God and actually figure out what that means.

I went to see a Tuesday movie just now, and randomly picked this movie called "Hail Caesar". It is one of those George Clooney movies with a serious theme to it. It is so serious that I fell asleep for half of it. However, in the end, I got the ultimate message of the year. There is something easy to do, and something hard to do in life. It is not necessarily a sin to do what is easy or... hard. God wants us to listen to the inner voice within each one of us, and do what is right--- and hopefully, what is in line with the holy wish of our Lord. 

This message is so important for me as I have been pondering on some real life related issues, and would like to share it with you. 

In Christ, 

Catherine

Going into my backyard, I love to see the products of nature -- mulberries, apples, rhubarbs, apples, roses, peonies... They are not even products of anyone's hard work, they are just there. Thanks to the green thumbs of our Creator. 

While I enjoyed the harvests of different sorts, I also frowned upon the weeds : ( . 

As I mulled over this paradoxical dilemma in my backyard, it dawned on me that the harvests and the weeds come as a package: Every generous dosage of nice surprise comes with a compatible amount of disappointment. This situation of course goes beyond what happens in my backyard. It is everywhere, in the world, in the community, among my loved ones, and ultimately within me. 

Upon the above realization, I uttered a little prayer for all of the parties mentioned above, that a) the weeds would not take over the harvest, b) I would learn to tolerate the disappointments I see in other people (with bottom line principles like safety and integrity of course) while enjoying the beauty in them.

One day, the statistics said that the employment rate has been up. The next day, the statistics said that the employment rate has been down. It does not really matter what the statistics says, and especially when you yourself is a number that makes up the statistics. The reason why I even ponder upon this issue is because I am concerned about the impact of this employment related challenge for people who are just starting out in their career and/or the "hardworking" people who do have a lot to offer to society, but have difficulty getting employment due to systemic issues, and in spite of their sincere efforts and sound judgment. 

If you are underemployed and unemployment, please do not give up!

post_title: Overcoming Trauma from a Car Crash
message:
I had a car accident recently, and it is amusing to reflect on the variety of conversations that people engage me in: sharing their own trauma, trying to find out if I have done anything wrong to cause it and lessons that I have learnt from it, turning this into their own stand up comedy on highway driving, displaying an inventory of their knowledge on the topic. 

As I reflected on what is going on in the above people's minds and lives when they behaved the way they did, and with the understanding that I am in the midst of people who love me in a genuine way, I came up with the hypothesis that these people are all trying to demonstrate their loving support for me, although these gestures of love might not have been done in a way that is helpful. 

Here's my intervention on the situation using my transparent approach and bringing out the dry sense of humour in me: I gently thanked people for their concern, and announced that I do not want the conversation to turn into a memorial service for my accident or ....theirs. 

As a matter of fact, I am thankful to our Lord for giving me another chance to experience His saving grace for incidents as such: when it was sunny out there, I was doing my normal driving following the traffic, somebody who apologized for her careless driving tailgated and rearended me, and I am still alive. I feel more like a victor than a victim: I do not have any control in preventing what happened that day, but my Lord helped me to conquer the trauma.

post_title: Even Potatoes are Peeled on His Time
message:
I asked for help to peel my potatoes, yams, squash and all kinds of in-season vegetables, while I was busy preparing supper. Nobody responded to my request--- until after supper. It dawned on me that I did not really need them for this supper. I can serve them in a party tomorrow. 

The butterflies in my stomach flew away momentarily. Yes, there is a time that things happen, and for a GOOOOOd reason.

My children do not need as much help in returning to school this fall. I may feel deprived of the excitement of new beginnings. However, I am working myself out of the wonderful job of parenting, and working towards the compatible joy of welcoming my children home as friends. This reminds me of Jesus' invitation for us to be his friend, to double up our inevitable call for help with fellowship through worship.

In spite of the culture that upholds the end justifies the means, I reflected upon the importance of integrity. One day, the straw and the wheat, the pebbles and diamonds, manipulation and genuine concern will show themselves.

August 25, 2010. Trapped miners in Chile… Sexual violence in Congo. They all have families. They all have souls and feelings. What does it matter what nationality they belong to? These traumas awakened in me our universal human connectedness. I bow and said a humble prayer for them, knowing full well that they are in the gracious arms of the Almighty.

Chinese Canadian died in a hostage taking tragedy. I was bawling as I listened to the news. Why him? Why his family? I do not know the victims from Adam. Nevertheless, this tragedy reminds me that good times, like having a family vacation, can turn out to be something that we least expect. We are all shadows and passerbys in this life. Let's go into each day clothed with vision, passion and action.

post_title: Getting Trapped in Seemingly Calm Waters
message: I had a good time at the cottage this weekend, until I was trapped by an undercurrent while kayaking. This reminds me of similar situations in life, and lessons learnt: Assess the environment and my assets for dealing with it, stay calm and prayerful, and be thankful.

I got up this morning, thinking about my to do list. 
I got up this morning, thinking about the people I miss.
I got up this morning, thinking about the things I need. 

I got up this morning, celebrating my achievements. 
I got up this morning, rejoicing over my circle of care. 
I got up this morning, enjoying what I have. 

I got up this morning, dancing and singing over my overflowing basket of blessings!
